questions.question: Which of the following is the manifestation of increased estrogen levels in Cirrhosis?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Palmar erythema Explanation: Increased estrogen levels in chronic liver failure lead to vascular changes, resulting in palmar erythema and spider angiomas. This condition can also cause hypogonadism and gynecomastia in males. Increased PT and aPTT (Option A) are primarily due to impaired synthesis of clotting factors by the damaged liver rather than the effects of hyperestrogenemia. Flapping tremors (aka asterixis) (Option B) are commonly associated with hepatic encephalopathy in cirrhosis, primarily due to elevated ammonia levels rather than estrogen. Jaundice (Option D) seen in cirrhosis is a result of impaired bilirubin metabolism due to liver dysfunction rather than being directly influenced by estrogen levels. Reference: Robbin’s Pathology, 10th edition, Page. 828

questions.question: Which of the following is not typically associated with developing fatty liver disease?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) Hepatitis B Explanation: Hepatitis B primarily affects the liver by causing inflammation and can lead to chronic liver disease, cirrhosis, and liver cancer, but it does not directly cause fatty liver disease. Fatty liver disease is often associated with several factors, such as alcoholism (Option D) , obesity, insulin resistance, metabolic syndrome, and type 2 diabetes (Option C). Chronic Hepatitis C (Option B) can cause liver inflammation and damage, potentially resulting in fat accumulation in the liver cells and leading to fatty liver disease. Reference: Robbins and Cotran, Pathological Basis of Disease, 10th Edition, Page 837, 842

questions.question: Which of the following is typically observed in liver biopsy findings of acute hepatitis A infection?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Councilman bodies Explanation: Councilman bodies, also known as acidophilic or apoptotic bodies, are eosinophilic structures representing apoptotic hepatocytes. These are characteristic findings of acute viral hepatitis. Biopsy findings of acute viral hepatitis Ballooning degeneration of hepatocytes Councilman bodies Spotty necrosis Dropout necrosis and Kupffer cell hyperplasia (Empty space lined by Kupffer cells) Absent or mild portal inflammation Interface hepatitis (Option A) is characterised by inflammatory cell infiltrates at the interface between the portal tracts and hepatic lobules and is prominent in Chronic viral hepatitis rather than acute. Ground glass hepatocytes (Option C) (aka Shikata cells) are densely eosinophilic cells with glassy cytoplasm due to HBsAg. They are seen in chronic Hepatitis B infection but not acute hepatitis. Bridging fibrosis (Option D) refers to fibrous septa or thick collagenous bands connecting adjacent portal tracts and central veins. It is typically observed in Chronic hepatitis and is indicative of advanced liver fibrosis. Reference: Robbins and Cotran, Pathological Basis of Disease, 10th Edition, Page831

questions.question: What is the most likely autoantibody detected in Type I autoimmune hepatitis (AIH)?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Anti-smooth muscle antibodies (ASMA) Explanation: Autoimmune hepatitis (AIH) is characterised by the presence of autoantibodies targeting various liver antigens. In Type 1 AIH, the most commonly detected autoantibody is anti-smooth muscle antibodies (ASMA), which target actin filaments in the smooth muscle cells of blood vessels and the liver. Features Type I AIH Type II AIH More common in Young female Children Auto-antibodies Anti SMA (Anti smooth muscle antibody) (Option B) ANA (Anti-nuclear antibody) Anti-soluble liver antigen Anti LKM- 1 (Hepatitis C) (Option A) Anti–liver cytosol-1 (ACL-1) (Option C) Anti LKM- 3 (Hepatitis D) Histopathology Interface hepatitis with a plasma cell-rich infiltrate. Foci of necrosis, ballooning degeneration of hepatocytes, and regenerative changes such as hepatocyte rosette formation. Reference: Robbins and Cotran, Pathological Basis of Disease, 10th Edition, Page839-840

questions.question: A 45-year-old male with diabetes mellitus presents with fatigue and abdominal discomfort. He denies any history of alcohol consumption. Laboratory tests show elevated serum AST and ALT levels. Imaging reveals hepatic steatosis. Which of the following is consistent with the patient's presentation?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) AST/ALT < 1 with diabetes mellitus Explanation: The clinical presentation is consistent with Non-alcoholic steatohepatitis, characterised by AST/ALT < 1. Features NASH (Non-alcoholic steatohepatitis) Alcoholic steatohepatitis Risk factors Obesity Diabetes mellitus (Option C) Dyslipidemia (Option D ruled out) Alcohol intake AST/ALT Ratio AST/ALT < 1 (Option A and B ruled out) AST/ALT > 2 GGT levels Normal Increased Reference: Robbins and Cotran, Pathological Basis of Disease, 10th Edition, Page 842- 846

questions.question: Which of the following changes is reversible with alcohol abstinence?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) Perivenular fibrosis Explanation: In the early stages of alcoholic liver disease, fibrosis typically begins around the central veins (central venules) in the liver lobules (perivenular or centrilobular zone) with a characteristic "chicken wire" appearance. With cessation of alcohol intake and appropriate treatment, this perivenular or pericellular fibrosis can regress, leading to improvement in liver function and histology. Reference: Robbins and Cotran, Pathological Basis of Disease, 10th Edition, Page 844

questions.question: Which of the following conditions is not typically associated with Mallory-Denk bodies?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Hemochromatosis Explanation: Among the given options, Hemochromatosis is not associated with Mallory-Denk bodies. Mallory-Denk bodies are seen in: Alcoholic liver disease (ALD) Non-alcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD) Indian childhood cirrhosis (ICC) (Option C) Wilson's disease (Option A) Alpha-1 antitrypsin deficiency (Option D) Hepatocellular carcinoma Cholestasis Hepatic or primary biliary diseases. Mallory-Denk bodies are not seen in: Hemochromatosis (Option B) Secondary biliary diseases. Reference: Robbins and Cotran, Pathological Basis of Disease, 10th Edition, Page 343

questions.question: A 51-year-old male with a history of chronic alcohol use presents with fatigue, abdominal discomfort, and unintentional weight loss. A biopsy of the liver was done. Which of the following histopathological features is characteristic of the condition depicted in the biopsy image?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) Mallory-Denk bodies Explanation: The histopathological feature characteristic of the condition depicted in the biopsy image is Mallory-Denk bodies , a hallmark of both alcohol-induced and nonalcoholic steatohepatitis. questions.question: A 60-year-old male presents with abdominal distension and jaundice. Examination reveals hepatosplenomegaly. Lab tests show elevated liver enzymes and decreased albumin levels. Imaging shows nodules <3mm throughout the liver. Which of the following conditions can present with these findings?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Hemochromatosis Explanation: The clinical presentation suggests micronodular liver cirrhosis with nodules <3mm. Hemochromatosis is one of the causes of micronodular cirrhosis. Causes of micronodular cirrhosis (Granule size <3mm) Causes of macronodular cirrhosis (Granule size >3mm) Early stage of Alcoholic Liver Disease (ALD) Indian Childhood Cirrhosis (ICC) Primary Biliary Cirrhosis (PBC) Hemochromatosis (Option C) Hepatic venous outflow obstruction (Budd-Chiari syndrome) Late stage of alcoholic liver disease (ALD) Viral hepatitis (Option A) Wilson disease (Option D) Drug-induced hepatitis (Option B) Alpha-1 antitrypsin deficiency

questions.question: Which cells are primarily involved in the fibrosis in liver cirrhosis?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Stellate cells Explanation: Hepatic stellate cells (or Ito cells) are pericytes located in the space of Disse, between hepatocytes and sinusoidal endothelial cells in the liver. In the healthy liver, these cells store vitamin A in lipid droplets and regulate sinusoidal blood flow. Upon liver injury, they activate and transform into myofibroblast-like cells, release TGF β , and lead to fibrosis by producing excessive extracellular matrix, such as collagen. Kupffer cells (Option A) are macrophages found in sinusoids of the liver, involved in phagocytosis. Pit cells (Option B) are liver-associated lymphocytes, primarily NK (Natural Killer) cells. They contribute to liver immune surveillance but are not directly implicated in liver fibrosis. Hepatocytes (Option D) are vital liver cells. Reference: Robbins and Cotran, Pathological Basis of Disease, 10th Edition, Page 824

questions.question: Which of the following stains would be most useful for highlighting collagen deposition in the fibrotic areas of the liver?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Masson's trichrome stain Explanation: Masson's trichrome stain is commonly used to visualize collagen fibers, making it suitable for highlighting fibrotic areas in liver tissue. questions.question: Which type of collagen is predominantly involved in the fibrotic process of cirrhosis?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) Collagen Type I and III Explanation: The fibrotic process in cirrhosis primarily involves activating hepatic stellate cells, leading to collagen deposition by myofibroblasts. These cells predominantly produce Collagen Types I and III. Reference: Robbins and Cotran, Pathological Basis of Disease, 10th Edition, Page 825, 826

A 35-year-old male presents with chronic jaundice and mild abdominal discomfort. Examination revealed hepatomegaly. Lab tests indicate elevated levels of direct bilirubin. Upon liver biopsy, a pigmented liver is observed. What is the most likely underlying mechanism for these clinical and pathological findings?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) MRP2 (Multidrug resistance-associated protein 2) defect Explanation: The clinical and pathological findings are consistent with Dubin-Johnson syndrome, which is characterised by impaired excretion of conjugated bilirubin into bile due to a defect in the MRP2 transporter leading to conjugated hyperbilirubinemia. The characteristic pigmented liver is due to the accumulation of epinephrine metabolite (not bilirubin). Type of hyperbilirubinemia Disorder Defect Unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia Crigler-Najjar syndrome type 1 Complete deficiency of UGT. (Option A) Crigler-Najjar syndrome type 2 Partial deficiency of UGT. Gilbert syndrome Very mild deficiency of UGT. Conjugated hyperbilirubinemia Dubin Johnson syndrome Defect in canalicular MRP2 protein. (Option C) Pigmented liver (due to epinephrine metabolite) Rotor syndrome Defect in ATPs (decreased biliary excretion) Non-pigmented liver Reference: Robbins and Cotran, Pathological Basis of Disease, 10th Edition, Page 852-854

questions.question: A 2-week-old infant presents with persistent jaundice since birth and markedly elevated unconjugated bilirubin levels (>20 mg/dL) despite exposure to sunlight. Genetic testing confirms homozygosity for a specific mutation. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) Crigler-Najjar syndrome type 1 Explanation: Based on the provided scenario, the likely diagnosis is Crigler-Najjar syndrome type 1, a rare autosomal recessive disorder characterised by the complete deficiency of the enzyme UDP-glucuronosyltransferase 1A1 (UGT1A1), leading to severe unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia. Without treatment, this condition can progress to kernicterus, a potentially fatal neurologic complication due to bilirubin deposition in the brain. It is 100% fatal if left untreated. Syndromes of Unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia Disorder Defect Severity of Unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia Crigler-Najjar syndrome type 1 (Option A) Complete deficiency of UGT Severe Crigler-Najjar syndrome type 2 (Option B) Partial deficiency of UGT Mild to moderate Gilbert syndrome (Option C) Very mild deficiency of UGT Mild, asymptomatic Syndromes of Conjugated hyperbilirubinemia Disorder Defect Gross Feature of liver Dubin Johnson syndrome Defect in canalicular MRP2 protein. Pigmented liver (due to epinephrine metabolite) Rotor syndrome (Option D) Defect in ATPs (decreased biliary excretion) Non pigmented liver Reference: Robbins and Cotran, Pathological Basis of Disease, 10th Edition, Page 856

questions.question: Which change can be seen in a structure that connects hepatocytes with cholangiocytes?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) Liver regeneration Explanation: The structure connecting hepatocytes with cholangiocytes is the Canals of Hering. It contains oval cells (aka liver stem cells), which play a pivotal role in liver regeneration. Therefore, changes observed in this structure are related to liver regeneration. Reference: Robbins and Cotran, Pathological Basis of Disease, 10th Edition, Page 824

questions.question: Which zone of the liver lobule is primarily affected by toxins and drug metabolism?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Zone 3 (perivenous zone) Explanation: Zone 3 (perivenous or pericentral) is primarily affected by toxins and drug metabolism because Zone 3 hepatocytes are close to the central vein and have the highest levels of cytochrome P450 enzymes. Zone Location Hepatocyte characteristics Sensitivity to Injury Zone 1 (periportal zone) (Option A) Around the portal tracts High oxygenation, reduced metabolic activity, Rich blood supply Least susceptibile to toxin-mediated and ischemic injury Zone 2 (mid zonal zone) (Option B) Between zone 1 and zone 3 Intermediate oxygenation, metabolic activity and blood supply Moderate susceptibility to toxin-mediated and ischemic injury Zone 3 (perivenous zone/ pericentral zone) (Option C) Around the central vein Low oxygenation, active metabolism, Poor blood supply Susceptible to drugs/toxin-mediated damage and ischemic injury during hypoperfusion of the liver Reference: Robbins and Cotran, Pathological Basis of Disease, 10th Edition, Page 823, 824
